title: Social Work Group Practice Exam Set 2
description: Comprehensive examination covering social group work concepts, practices, and applications. Set 2 of 3. All questions written in clear, student-friendly language with practical examples and step-by-step explanations.

questions.question: Group work as a method of social work was primarily defined by:

options.B: Enhancing social functioning through purposeful group experiences

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Enhancing social functioning through purposeful group experiences

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Individual therapy principles) - This focuses on individuals rather than understanding how the whole group develops and changes.
• **C** (Community organizing only) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Administrative management) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: According to the document, which is NOT a characteristic of a group?

options.D: Members see themselves as part of the group

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: C** - Random gathering without interaction

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Two or more people) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **B** (Shared goals) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Members see themselves as part of the group) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: The difference between formed groups and natural groups is:

options.B: Formed groups meet due to external influence; natural groups form through mutual attraction

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Formed groups meet due to external influence; natural groups form through mutual attraction

**Why this is correct:** Understanding the difference between groups that form naturally (like friends) versus groups that are created by someone else (like therapy groups) helps social workers use the right approach for each type.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Size of membership) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Natural groups have paid facilitators) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Formed groups have no structure) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: When a group serves as a "target of change," the focus is on:

options.B: Changing group structure, procedures, or processes

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Changing group structure, procedures, or processes

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Individual therapy) - This focuses on individuals rather than understanding how the whole group develops and changes.
• **C** (Community development) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (External advocacy) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Out-groups are characterized by:

options.B: Not identifying themselves with the group

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Not identifying themselves with the group

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Strong group identity) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (High cohesiveness) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Mutual support) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Group use for collective problem solving emphasizes:

options.B: Pooling ideas and group thinking about situations

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Pooling ideas and group thinking about situations

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Individual solutions) - This focuses on individuals rather than understanding how the whole group develops and changes.
• **C** (Competition among members) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (External expert solutions) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: The concept of "mutual aid" in group work refers to:

options.B: Members helping each other achieve individual and group goals

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Members helping each other achieve individual and group goals

**Why this is correct:** William Schwartz discovered that people in groups can help each other solve problems better than a worker helping each person individually. It's like having a team where everyone contributes their strengths.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Financial assistance) - Mutual aid in social work isn't about money - it's about people supporting each other emotionally and socially.
• **C** (Agency support) - Mutual aid happens between group members themselves, not from the agency providing support.
• **D** (Professional intervention only) - This misses the key point of mutual aid - that group members help each other, not just the professional helping everyone.

**Source:** Based on William Schwartz's mutual aid model (1961)

questions.question: Which statement best describes the humanistic theme in developmental approach?

options.B: Viewing human beings with respect and untapped potential

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Viewing human beings with respect and untapped potential

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Viewing people as problems) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Focusing on pathology) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Emphasizing control and authority) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: The phenomenological aspect of the Developmental Approach focuses on:
questions.explanation:

**Why this is correct:** This approach sees groups as places where people can practice social skills and grow, like a safe practice space before facing real-world challenges.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Past behavior analysis) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **C** (Future predictions) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **D** (Unconscious motivations) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.

questions.explanation:

• **D** (Situations create leaders) - This doesn't reflect how successful groups organize themselves and their activities.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: Group norms can be changed through all EXCEPT:

options.B: High status members with idiosyncrasy credit

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: C** - External force without group agreement

**Why this is correct:** Group norms are unwritten rules about behavior, like how families have their own ways of doing things. They help groups function smoothly.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Behavioral contagion) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.
• **B** (High status members with idiosyncrasy credit) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.
• **D** (Group discussion) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.

**Source:** Based on Toseland & Rivas group work principles (2017)

questions.question: Written rules in groups represent:

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Informal agreements) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Unspoken expectations) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

questions.question: The "storming" stage in Tuckman's model is characterized by:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Conflict and resistance

**Why this is correct:** Bruce Tuckman's research shows that all groups go through predictable stages as they develop, just like how people grow from childhood to adulthood. This helps social workers know what to expect and how to help groups succeed.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Harmony and agreement) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (High productivity) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Member departure) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Real-world example:** In a teen anger management group, members might challenge the leader's rules or argue about how the group should be run.

**Source:** Based on Bruce Tuckman's research on group development (1965)

questions.question: During the "norming" stage, groups develop:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Cohesiveness and close relationships

**Why this is correct:** Bruce Tuckman's research shows that all groups go through predictable stages as they develop, just like how people grow from childhood to adulthood. This helps social workers know what to expect and how to help groups succeed.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Initial anxiety) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Major conflicts) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Termination plans) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Real-world example:** A parenting skills group develops an unspoken rule that everyone gets to share before anyone speaks twice, creating fairness.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: The "performing" stage features:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Focus on goal achievement

**Why this is correct:** Bruce Tuckman's research shows that all groups go through predictable stages as they develop, just like how people grow from childhood to adulthood. This helps social workers know what to expect and how to help groups succeed.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Initial orientation) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Power struggles) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Separation anxiety) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.

**Real-world example:** In a new support group for people dealing with grief, members might be quiet and polite at first, unsure about sharing personal feelings with strangers.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

options.B: Help them negotiate with employment systems

• **A** (Past failures) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **C** (Psychiatric referral) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.
• **D** (Removal from group) - This approach wouldn't be effective in real social work practice with groups.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: During termination phase, members request the worker's personal contact information. The worker should:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Discuss boundaries and alternative resources

**Why this is correct:** Groups develop in predictable ways, and knowing these patterns helps social workers guide groups more effectively.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Provide it freely) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **C** (Be offended) - This doesn't match what research tells us about how groups naturally develop over time.
• **D** (Ignore the request) - Ignoring or avoiding issues is not an effective social work approach - problems need to be addressed directly.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: A task group cannot agree on project direction after five meetings. This suggests need for:

options.B: Clarification of goals and decision-making process

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Clarification of goals and decision-making process

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Group dissolution) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (New members) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (External authority) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: In a group for caregivers, one member never speaks. Using group process knowledge, the worker should:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Create safe opportunities for participation

**Why this is correct:** Understanding how groups work helps social workers create positive environments where people can help each other.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Force participation) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.
• **C** (Ignore the silence) - Ignoring or avoiding issues is not an effective social work approach - problems need to be addressed directly.
• **D** (Remove the member) - This misunderstands how group interactions and relationships actually work.

**Source:** Based on Toseland & Rivas group work principles (2017)

questions.question: A worker facilitating a job skills group notices members helping each other outside sessions with resumes. This should be:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Encouraged as mutual aid development

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Prohibited immediately) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Reported to agency) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Ignored) - Ignoring or avoiding issues is not an effective social work approach - problems need to be addressed directly.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: During a school-based social skills group, children start excluding one member. The worker should:

options.B: Address inclusion as a group issue

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Address inclusion as a group issue

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Let them work it out) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Remove the excluded child) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Punish the excluders) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: A social worker planning a group for elderly residents considers group size. For a support group, optimal size would be:
questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - 5-7 members

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (15-20 members) - This doesn't reflect how successful groups organize themselves and their activities.
• **C** (2-3 members) - This doesn't reflect how successful groups organize themselves and their activities.
• **D** (Over 20 members) - This doesn't reflect how successful groups organize themselves and their activities.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: In a group for persons with disabilities, the agency lacks wheelchair access. The worker should:

options.B: Advocate for accessibility or find alternative space

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Advocate for accessibility or find alternative space

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Proceed anyway) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Exclude wheelchair users) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Cancel the group) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: During evaluation, group goals were partially met. This indicates:

options.B: Need for analysis of facilitating and hindering factors

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Need for analysis of facilitating and hindering factors

**Why this is correct:** Professional ethics provide guidelines to ensure that social workers help people in ways that are safe, fair, and effective.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Complete failure) - This goes against professional social work standards and ethical guidelines.
• **C** (Member inadequacy) - This goes against professional social work standards and ethical guidelines.
• **D** (Worker incompetence) - This goes against professional social work standards and ethical guidelines.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards

questions.question: A worker notices decreasing attendance in a long-term group. This might indicate:

options.B: Need to reassess group purpose and member needs

questions.explanation:
**Correct Answer: B** - Need to reassess group purpose and member needs

**Why this is correct:** This concept is important for effective social work practice because it helps workers understand how to work with groups successfully.

**Why the other options are wrong:**
• **A** (Poor location only) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **C** (Member pathology) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.
• **D** (Agency failure) - This doesn't align with established social work principles and research.

**Source:** Based on established social work research and practice standards
